citation.article-title: Bifidobacterium gallinarum sp. nov.: a new species isolated from the ceca of chickens.

p.s: Bifidobacterium gallinarum (gal.li.na'rum L. n. gallina hen; L. gen. pl. n. gallinarum of hens)
Gram-positive , nonmotile, nonsporeforming, slightly curved, short rods (0.5 to 1.0 μm wide by 1.0 to 2.5 μm long) with tapered ends, usually arranged singly or in short chains.
Swellings or club-shaped cells are frequent.
In liquid aged cultures some cells have short

Surface colonies on BL agar after 2 days of anaerobic incubation are punctiform to 1 mm in diameter, circular, entire, flat to convex, gray to grayish white, transparent to translucent, and glistening.
Final pH of glucose or fructose broth: 4.5 to 5.1.
Acid from xylose, ribose, fructose, sucrose, maltose, melibiose, raffinose, inulin, dextrin, esculin, salicin, and amygdalin.
Arabinose, glucose, mannose, galactose, cellobiose, lactose, trehalose, and α-methylglucoside usually fermented.
Rhamnose, starch, glycogen, mannitol, sorbitol, and inositol not fermented.
No gas formation from glucose or fructose.
Fermentation products from glucose or fructose are lactic acid and acetic acid in a molar ratio of 1:4.0±0.2 in EG broth containing these carbohydrates.
Propionic acid and butyric acid are never formed.
